edu.macalester.acs
Class AutocompleteTree<K extends java.lang.Comparable,V>

java.lang.Object
  edu.macalester.acs.BaseAutocompleter<K,V>
      edu.macalester.acs.AutocompleteTree<K,V>
All Implemented Interfaces:
Autocompleter<K,V>
public class AutocompleteTree<K extends java.lang.Comparable,V>
extends BaseAutocompleter<K,V>

        implements Autocompleter<K,V>

Supports autocomplete queries on some entities. Autocomplete queries return entities whose name begins with a query.

Autocomplete queries may have more matches than the user desires. For examples, thousands of cities that start with 'S'. Each entity has a score associated with it that is used to decide which entities to return when there are too many matches.

Every entity entry has a unique key (such as a database identifier), a value (the entity), and a score. These three pieces of information are stored in an instanc of the AutocompleteEntry class. The key should be a unique identifier for an entity such as a database id. The value should contain data that your application needs to provide about the entity in the external autocomplete interface, such as a name or description. The keys must implement reasonable hashCode, compareTo, and equals methods.

Entities may have multiple names, called "fragments." For example, if an entity for the 44th president of the United States wants to support prefix matching against "Barack Hussain Obama," "Barack Obama" and "Obama" it will have fragments for each of these pseudonyms. Each fragment is stored in an instance of the AutocompleteFragment class, which simply stores a (textual fragment, autocomplete entry) pair.

This class uses a fragmenter that provides string normalization and fragmentation. It normalizes both query strings and fragments (e.g. converts Shilad W. Sen to shilad w sen. And also fragments as described earlier. By default, a SimpleFragmenter is used, but you can specify your own fragmenter.

This implementation optionally caches results for short prefixes. The maximum cached query length can be controlled by changing the maxCacheQueryLength attribute. Setting this to one or two (default is 2) can dramatically speed up the number of queries at the cost of increased memory. The number of results stored for a particular prefix is specified by the numCacheResults attribute. This should ideally be equal to the maxResults parameter passed to the autocomplete method. Cache entries are automatically invalidated when entries are created, removed, or when their score is updated.

An example usage for the tree for entities of the example City class: 


     AutocompleteTree
      tree = new AutocompleteTree
     ();
     tree.add(1, new City("Chicago", "Illinois"));
     tree.add(2, new City("Moline", "Illinois"));
     tree.add(3, new City("Minneapolis", "Minnesota"));
     tree.add(4, new City("St. Paul", "Minnesota"));
     tree.add(5, new City("Boston", "Massachussets"));
     ...

     tree.increment(5); // increments the score for Boston by 1.
     tree.setScore(3, 9.0); // sets the score for Minneapolis to 9.0;

     SortedSet
     > results = tree.autocomplete("ch", 3);
     for (AutocompleteEntry
      entry : results) {
     System.out.println("city " + entry.getValue() + " with score " + entry.getScore());
     }
This class should be thread-safe. TODO:
  • Enable the autocomplete() method to supply a predicate so that it can only match a subset of the entities in the tree. E.g. just show me People starting with "fo." Adjust the cache so that it is predicate aware, perhaps by asking the caller to define a named "scope" associated with the passed-in predicate.
  • Support lucene (or something similar) as a persistent, disk-based datastructure.
  • Explore ways of improving locks so that threading scales better.
  • Optimize cache invalidation logic.

Author:
Shilad Sen

getEntries

public java.util.Collection<AutocompleteEntry<K,V>> getEntries()
Returns a collection of all the autocomplete entries in the tree. This is an expensive operation memory-wise, since the list is copied. We need to do this to ensure that underlying collection is not changed by the caller.

Returns:

setScore

public void setScore(K key,
                     double score)
Sets the score of the entry associated with the key. This function MUST be used to set the score of an entry once it is in the tree. Otherwise, the tree will get very confused.

autocomplete

public java.util.SortedSet<AutocompleteEntry<K,V>> autocomplete(java.lang.String domain,
                                                                java.lang.String query,
                                                                AutocompleteFilter<K,V> filter,
                                                                int maxResults)
Description copied from interface: Autocompleter
Executes an autocomplete search against the stored entries. Before comparing the query to fragments, each is normalized using the fragmenter (or SimpleFragmenter if none was specified) If there are more than maxResults that begin with the query, the highest-score results are returned.

Specified by:
autocomplete in interface Autocompleter<K extends java.lang.Comparable,V>
maxResults - Maximum number of results that are returned.
Returns:
